projectPurpose: To provide a high-performance, full-featured library for building custom full-text search engines, inspired by Apache Lucene but written in Rust.
mainFeatures: Fast performance and tiny startup time
Natural query language and phrase queries
Support for various field types (Text, numeric, date, IP, boolean, facets, JSON)

alternatives.name: Apache Lucene
mainFeatures: Numerous query types (wildcard, phrase, proximity, range)
Pluggable ranking models (BM25, Vector Space Model)

alternatives.name: Elasticsearch
alternatives.license: Triple-licensed (Elastic License, SSPL, AGPL) - Primarily Proprietary/Source-Available
mainFeatures: RESTful API and schema-free JSON documents

alternatives.name: Apache Solr
mainFeatures: Full-text search with hit highlighting and faceting

marketPositioning: Tantivy is positioned as a high-performance, Rust-native full-text search *library*, serving as a direct alternative to Apache Lucene for developers who require an embeddable search engine or wish to build custom search solutions. Unlike full-fledged search servers like Elasticsearch and Apache Solr, which offer distributed capabilities and a complete server stack, Tantivy focuses on providing the core indexing and searching primitives with a strong emphasis on speed, low-level control, and the benefits of the Rust programming language. This makes it suitable for applications where embedding the search functionality is preferred or where a custom search server needs to be built from the ground up, leveraging Rust's performance and safety features.
